title: U.S. Military Forces in FY 2022: Space, SOF, Civilians, and Contractors
description: This paper is part of U.S. Military Forces in FY 2022. Military forces include the Space Force, Special Operations Forces, DOD civilians, and contractors.

title: Is China Building a New String of Pearls in the Atlantic Ocean?
description: Reports have emerged that China seeks to establish a military base in the Central African nation of Equatorial Guinea. If plans move ahead, the Port of Bata is the most suitable for the Chinese navy and it would help China project military power into the Atlantic Ocean.

title: Ships Don’t Lie: Blockchain and a Secure Future for Global Shipping
description: The resiliency of the global shipping sector will depend on the industry’s adaptation of blockchain technology. A new CQ from the Scholl Chair explores.

title: Five Things to Watch in 2022
description: CSIS Economics Program experts Matthew P. Goodman, Gerard DiPippo, Jonathan E. Hillman, and Matthew Reynolds look ahead to the coming year and highlight five issues in international economic affairs they will be tracking in 2022.

title: Methane Emissions and the Gas Ecosystem: Buyers, Sellers, and Banks
description: Reducing methane emissions can slow the pace of global warming, and the quick wins in the oil and gas sector will come on the supply side. But changing the way that natural gas is traded can also play a role, especially if gas buyers begin to focus on methane intensity.

title: China Is Ramping Up Its Electronic Warfare and Communications Capabilities near the South China Sea
description: Recent satellite imagery reveals that China has made major improvements to its electronic warfare, communications, and intelligence gathering capabilities near the South China Sea through the rapid expansion of facilities on Hainan Island.

title: Venezuela: A Time for Opposition Reflection and Renovation
description: CSIS Americas senior fellow Ryan C. Berg and senior associate Alexandra Winkler assess Venezuela's recent regional elections and negotiations between the regime and opposition in Mexico City and make recommendations for revitalizing the Venezuelan opposition.

title: Assuring U.S. Global Competitiveness in Science, Technology and Commerce
description: The CSIS Renewing American Innovation Project is pleased to host a conversation with Representative Haley Stevens (D-MI-11) about the future of U.S. competitiveness in science, technology and innovation led by RAI senior adviser and former NIST director Walter Copan.

title: Experts React: The 2021 Summit for Democracy
description: CSIS experts comment on the impact, challenges faced, and road ahead for the Biden administration’s 2021 Summit for Democracy and its subsequent year of action.

title: Will the Dual Circulation Strategy Enable China to Compete in a Post-Pandemic World?
description: To shield China from global volatility and pivot the Chinese economy toward greater self-reliance, Beijing is pursuing a new economic model centering on the Dual Circulation Strategy.

title: Lebanon’s Growing Humanitarian Crisis
description: A humanitarian emergency is growing among Lebanese. Overlaps in humanitarian responses risk fueling tensions and wasting limited aid resources. CSIS's Will Todman and Caleb Harper argue that an independent review is necessary to maximize the effectiveness of humanitarian aid.

title: Aspirations to Action: Making the Refugee Compact Work for the Rohingya
description: The success of the Global Compact on Refugees (GCR) in countries like Bangladesh lies on host country engagement on refugee policies and shared international responsibility to provide consistent, flexible funding and create greater opportunities for resettlement.
